Running GitHub Actions Locally

Maximilian Held

2019-08-01

Source: vignettes/local.Rmd
local.Rmd

This is unofficial documentation for GitHub Actions in general, based on the experience of developing this R package. GitHub Actions is still in limited beta, and the features described here may change quickly. Here is the official documentation.

For fast turnaround or debugging, you can also run GitHub actions locally on your computer. For some projects, GitHub actions may even serve as a replacement for make.

Because it is based on Docker containers and an open workflow format, there are already several local, open-source workflow runners, including:

  • act
  • popper
  • gha

None of these are officially supported by GitHub, and they may differ from the GitHub actions (the hosted service) in subtle ways. Consult the respective issue issue trackers for known limitations.

act currently appears to be the most comprehensive and mature alternative. Installation and usage is documented here how to install it.

Secrets

To run act with secrets, you can enter them interactively or supply them as environment variables. If you have a secret called FOO in your main.workflow, act will take whatever you have set as FOO in the session from which you are running act. If FOO is unset, it will ask you interactively.

You can set environment variables for the current session by running export FOO="zap", or globally in your .profile. You can also set environment variables per directory using a tool such as direnv.

Be careful not to expose secrets: You may want to .gitignore any files or folders containing secrets, and/or encrypt secrets.

Skipping Actions in act

You may sometimes want to skip some actions when you’re running a main.workflow in act, such as deployment. You can achieve something similar by using a filter action, filtering on all GITHUB_ACTORs except nektos/act, which is the GITHUB_ACTOR set by act.

action "Filter Not Act" {
  uses = "actions/bin/filter@3c0b4f0e63ea54ea5df2914b4fabf383368cd0da"
  args = "not actor nektos/act"
}

Just remember that GitHub actions will cancel all upcoming and concurrent actions on a neutral exit code. To avoid prematurely cancelling actions, place this filter at the latest possible point in the build graph.
